wikipedia_page.main: Simon Shaw-Miller (born 1960) is the professor of history of art at the University of Bristol. He is a specialist in the relationships between art and music in the modern period.

response: In France Obukhov met and studied with Maurice Ravel, who not only showed some interest in his music but provided financial assistance for the refugee family and set Obukhov up with a publisher.Sitsky, 254 While he at first lived in poverty, he was able to obtain sufficient outside help to be able to focus on composition and associated projects. These projects included the development of an electronic instrument, the croix sonore, a device similar to the theremin but built in the shape of a cross, with the electronics hidden inside a brass orb to which the cross was affixed.Hugh Davies. "Croix sonore." In Grove Music Online. Oxford Music Online, http://www.oxfordmusiconline.com/subscriber/article/grove/music/53322 (accessed 23 January 2011). He worked with Pierre Dauvillier and Michel Billaudot on the construction of the device, probably at different times. They demonstrated a prototype of the croix sonore in 1926, withdrawing it to create a refined version in 1934; many of Obukhov's concurrent and subsequent works use the instrument.Simon Shaw-Miller. Visible Deeds of Music: Art and Music from Wagner to Cage. Yale University Press, 1959. 75–79.   A diagram of the croix sonore appears on page 77.
* The Viennese Café and Fin-de-siècle Culture. Berghahn Books, 2013. (co-editor with Charlotte Ashby and Simon Shaw-Miller)
